the high pressure side, high pressure liquid is piped from the high pressure receiver and into the subcooler plates. The low pressure liquid in the heat exchanger absorbs heat from the high pressure liquid on the other side of each plate. The subcooled high pressure liquid exits the subcooler and is supplied to each zone of refrigeration. Under normal conditions, the subcooler contains low and high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Recirculators (Accumulator 5 and Accumulator 6)
The purpose of Accumulators 5-6 (Process 1) is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid that can be used in evaporators throughout the facility. Accumulators 5-6 receive liquid from the high pressure receiver and supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the ammonia pumps mounted underneath the vessels. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators is separated inside Accumulators 5-6 to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Accumulators 5-6 are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, Accumulators 5-6 contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Oil Pots
The purpose of the oil pots is to provide a safe location to drain oil from the refrigeration system. The oil pots receive liquid ammonia and oil from the recirculator and vent ammonia vapor back to the recirculator. The oil pots are equipped with spring-return oil drain valves which are used to drain oil from the system as needed. Under normal conditions, the oil pots contain low pressure liquid ammonia, low pressure vapor ammonia, and refrigerant oil.

Air-Cooling Evaporators (Flooded)
The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators (flooded) is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from the flooded accumulators. The evaporators contain a set o

pe in the system is summarized below:

High Pressure Receiver
The purpose of the high pressure receivers is to provide a safe location to add and store high pressure liquid ammonia in the refrigeration systems. The high pressure receivers receive high pressure liquid from the condensers and supply high pressure liquid to each zone of refrigeration and liquid recirculator. The high pressure receivers are also used to provide storage for ammonia not being used in the process at any given moment. The high pressure receivers are each equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the systems. Under normal conditions, the high pressure receivers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Flooded Accumulators
The purpose of each flooded accumulator is to provide a supply of low pressure liquid ammonia to the evaporators/hydrocoolers. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the vessel. The flooded accumulators supply, by gravity, low pressure liquid to the associated evaporators and hydrocooler coils. Liquid and vapor returned from the evaporators and hydrocoolers is separated inside the flooded accumulators to allow only the vapor to be returned to the main suction accumulator or recirculator. Under normal conditions, the flooded accumulators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Subcooler
The subcooler receives and subcools liquid from the P2 high pressure receiver in order to supply subcooled liquid to the flooded accumulators. The subcooler is a plate and frame heat exchanger that uses a supply of low temperature ammonia to cool high pressure liquid ammonia. On the low temperature side, the subcooler is equipped with an expansion valve which expands high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the heat exchanger. On

1.2.3 Description of Covered Processes

The refrigerated zones in Building A Room 3/4, Building B, Building C, Building D, Building E, the Chilled Water Pit, and the Fumigation Rooms are equipped with evaporators and accumulators as required for flooded operation while Building A Rooms 1, 2, 5, and 6 are equipped with evaporators and a pump recirculator as required for pumped overfeed operation. All control valve groups are mounted on the roof (Building B, C, D, and E) or near the high side machinery area (Building A) to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within two (2) refrigeration machinery rooms, (1) outdoor high-side skid, and directly outside near the machinery rooms. Process Chemistry

The refrigeration systems employed at OG Packing and Cold Storage are configured for a combination of flooded and pumped overfeed operation. Process 1 is configured for both flooded and pumped overfeed operation, and Process 2 is configured for flooded operation. The function and thermodynamics of each major component ty

All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

OG Packing & Cold Storage has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, OG Packing & Cold Storage continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved OG Packing & Cold Storage's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that OG Packing & Cold Storage's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.

OG Packing & Cold Storage has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, OG Packing & Cold Storage has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.

For the future, OG Packing & Cold Storage now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a living document. It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for OG Packing & Cold Storage employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program OG Packin

and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration processes. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration processes at the OG Packing & Cold Storage facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates continuously from spring to early summer, the rest of the year the system continues to run as required to store outside product. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

1.4 Five Year Accident History

OG Packing & Cold Storage has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

OG Packing & Cold Storage's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR §3220
U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR §1910.38
Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR §5189(n)
U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]- Title 29 CFR §1910.119(n)
California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 §2765.1-2765.2
USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR §68.95
California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 §2731

Strategically, we will respond minimally to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility.

sure equals or exceeds the setpoint.
Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.
Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.

High Level Float Switches
The main suction accumulator (Process 2) and liquid recirculators (Process 1) are equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressor.

Main Liquid Feed Shut-Off Valve (King Valve)
The Process 2 high pressure receiver is equipped with a main liquid feed shut-off valve (king valve) that is clearly labeled and can be used to stop the flow of ammonia throughout the system. Process 1 is equipped with several valves that must be closed to stop the flow of ammonia to the system.

Emergency Refrigeration Switch (E-Stop)
Each process is equipped with an emergency refrigeration switch that controls power to the refrigeration machinery inside the machinery rooms. The switches can be activated in an emergency by pressing the button.

1.2.4 Process Classification

Each ammonia refrigeration system at OG Packing consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at OG Packing are treated as two (2) independent processes.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

OG Packing & Cold Storage has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case

s, the ammonia diffusion tank contains water.

The Process 2 horizontal ammonia diffusion tank is 8'-0' dia. x 28'-0 long (10,418 gallon capacity). At a water level of 5'-3, the tank contains 7,584 gallons of water which exceeds the quantity recommended by ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A §15.5.3 which is based on 1 gallon of water per pound of ammonia released through the largest relief valve in the system in 60 minutes. Under normal conditions, the ammonia diffusion tank contains water.

Screw Compressor Safety Devices
Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each screw compressor package:
High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pressure equals or exceeds the setpoint.
Low Suction Pressure Cutout - The low suction pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the suction pressure is equal to or less than the setpoint.
Oil Pressure Cutout - The oil pressure cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil pressure equals or deviates below the setpoint.
High Oil Temperature Cutout - The high oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.
Low Oil Temperature Cutout - The low oil temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the oil temperature equals or falls below the setpoint.
Discharge Temperature Cutout - The high discharge temperature cutout will shut down the compressor if the discharge temperature equals or exceeds the setpoint.

Reciprocating Compressor Safety Devices
Each reciprocating compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. The following list summarizes the safety devices built into each compressor package:
High Discharge Pressure Cutout - The high discharge pressure cutout, will shut down the compressor if the discharge pres

emergency pressure control systems (EPCS) were installed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A Appendix I and the 2016 California Fire Code. Each EPCS consists of a crossover solenoid valve which connects the high stage discharge (HSD) pipe to the high temperature suction (HTS) pipe. Each EPCS operates as follows: 
EPCS is activated at not greater than 90% pressure relief valve setting (e.g. 270 psig or less) [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.3] 
Upon activation, all compressors are stopped by a means that is independent of all other safety controls [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.6] 
Upon activation, crossover solenoid valve is opened [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.6] 
Upon activation, a signal is provided to personnel responsible for refrigeration system maintenance [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.7] 
EPCS remains active until manually reset [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.5.8]
EPCS crossover isolation valves are locked open [ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Appendix I.4.4.2]

Relief Valves
All ASME pressure vessels and positive displacement compressors are equipped with relief valves designed to relieve pressure and protect the equipment from rupturing. Details regarding the relief valves are summarized below:
All relief valves are connected to a common manifold which terminates into the ammonia diffusion tank; 

Diffusion Tank
The refrigeration systems are each equipped with an ammonia diffusion tank which mitigates most of the hazards associated with a relief valve lifting. The relief valve discharge piping is terminated at the bottom of the ammonia diffusion tanks. 

The Process 1 ammonia diffusion tank is 6'-6' dia. x 14'-0' high (3,500 gallon capacity). At a water level of 11'-6, the tank contains 2,854 gallons of water which exceeds the quantity recommended by ANSI/IIAR 2-2014 Addendum A §15.5.3 which is based on 1 gallon of water per pound of ammonia released through the largest relief valve in the system in 60 minutes. Under normal condition

tions, the compressors contain both high and low pressure vapor ammonia.

Evaporative Condensers
The purpose of the evaporative condensers is to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators to the atmosphere. The evaporative condensers receive high pressure, superheated vapor from the compressors and supply high pressure liquid to the high pressure receivers and oil coolers. The condensers use air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver and oil coolers. Under normal conditions, the evaporative condensers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Oil Coolers
The purpose of the oil coolers is to remove heat from the oil being circulated through them. The oil coolers receive liquid from the condensers. High pressure liquid and vapor exits the oil coolers and is returned to the condensers. Under normal conditions, the oil coolers contain high pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.
Safety Systems

Ammonia Detection System
The ammonia detection system at OG Packing and Cold Storage consists of the following locations (generally on the center beam in each cold room):
Machinery Room 1 - (1) Coolair LBW-50
Line 1 Hydrocooler
Room 1 - (1) Coolair LBW-50
Room 2 - (1) Coolair LBW-50
Room 3/4
Room 5 - (1) Coolair LBW-50
Room 6 - (1) Coolair LBW-50
Machinery Room 2 - (1) Coolair LBW-50
Building B/Rooms 1-4 - Sample system consisting of a sensor, vacuum pump, and tubing
Building C - (3) sensors near Line 2, Line 3 and north wall
Building D - (2) Coolair LBW-50
Building E - (1) Coolair LBW-50

Each sensor is tied into a local audible/visual alarm as well as a notification in the Shipping Office. The alarm will also send a text message to the Production Maintenance Manager 24 hours/day. Sensors are set to 25 ppm. 

Emergency Pressure Control System
The

il and is returned to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the pit coil contains low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Main Suction Accumulator
The purpose of the main suction accumulator (Process 2) is to prevent liquid from entering the compressors. The main suction accumulator receives vapor from the flooded accumulators and separates any residual liquid from the vapor to allow only the vapor to be piped to the suction of each compressor. Liquid in the main suction accumulator drains by gravity into the liquid transfer pump. The main suction accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressors. Under normal conditions, the main suction accumulator contains low pressure vapor ammonia.

Liquid Transfer Vessel 
The purpose of the liquid transfer vessel is to transfer liquid from the low side of the refrigeration system back to the high pressure receiver. The liquid transfer vessel receives liquid from Accumulator 5. Once the liquid level in the liquid transfer vessel reaches the float switch, the three way solenoid valve is energized for a period of time causing the liquid transfer vessel to become subject to high pressure and allowing the liquid to drain by gravity into the high pressure receiver. Under normal conditions the liquid transfer vessel can contain either high or low pressure liquid and vapor.

Compressors
The purpose of the compressors is to raise the temperature and pressure of the low pressure gas in order to reject the heat absorbed in the evaporators and hydrocoolers to the atmosphere. The compressors receive low pressure vapor from the main suction accumulator or Accumulator 5 and discharge high pressure vapor to the evaporative condensers. The compressors are equipped with high discharge pressure cutouts to shut the equipment off if the pressure exceeds the setpoint. Under normal condi

f continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Air-Cooling Evaporators (Pumped Overfeed)
The purpose of the air-cooling evaporators (pumped overfeed) is to remove heat from the air in order to maintain a predetermined space temperature. The air-cooling evaporators receive liquid from Accumulators 5-6. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporators use an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it returns to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the air-cooling evaporators contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Hydrocoolers
The purpose of the hydrocoolers is to remove heat from water which is used to precool fresh fruit. The hydrocoolers receive liquid from the flooded accumulators. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the hydrocoolers and is returned to the supplying vessel. Under normal conditions, the hydrocoolers contain low pressure liquid and vapor ammonia.

Pit Coil 
The purpose of the pit coil is to produce ice that can be used for packaging finished products. The pit coil receives liquid from Accumulator 6. Low pressure liquid and vapor exits the pit co

afety. We have: 
1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Descriptions

1.2.1 Facility Overview

OG Packing and Cold Storage operates a commercial packing and storage facility for cherries and walnuts in Stockton, CA. The facility has two (2) ammonia systems which provide refrigeration capacity to the following:

Process 1
(5) Building A Cold Storage Rooms (Room 1, Room 2, Room 3/4, Room 5, and Room 6)
(1) Hydrocooler (Line 1)
(1) Chilled Water Pit
(2) Fumigation Rooms 

Process 2
(4) Building B Cold Storage Rooms
(1) Building B Hallway
(1) Building D Packing Room
(1) Building E Cold Storage Room
(3) Hydrocoolers (Receiving, Line 2, and Line 3) 

1.2.2 Facility Location

OG Packing is located at 2097 Beyer Ln. Stockton, CA 95215. The latitude and longitude of the largest high pressure receiver is 37.985976, -121.232797. The facility is located approximately 1 mile east of state highway 99 in a rural area surrounded by agricultural land and residential areas.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is partly located in a special flood hazard area. The elevation of the machinery room was designed with the flood hazards in mind.
OG Packing is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that OG Packing has a 1-2% chance of experiencing potentially minor-damage due to ground shaking in

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR §68
- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR §5189
- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, OG Packing & Cold Storage has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1 OG Packing & Cold Storage, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that OG Packing & Cold Storage has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                 | Process Chemical                | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Process 1                      Anhydrous Ammonia                 16,000
Process 2                      Anhydrous Ammonia                 20,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. 
Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public s
